sub_topic: The Hausdorff dimension of the Cantor dust.
message_1: What is the Hausdorff dimension of the Cantor set obtained by removing the middle third of a line segment of length 1, $k$ times? For instance, find the Hausdorff dimension of the Cantor set obtained by removing the middle thirds of the interval $[0, 1]$ and the middle thirds of each of the two remaining line segments.
message_2:
The Hausdorff dimension of the Cantor set obtained by removing the middle third of a line segment of length 1, k times can be found using the formula:

Hausdorff dimension = $\frac{\log N}{\log (1/s)}$

where N is the number of self-similar pieces and s is the scaling factor.

In the case of the Cantor set, after each iteration, there are 2 self-similar pieces (N = 2) and the scaling factor is 3 (s = 3) because each remaining segment is 1/3 the length of the previous segment.

So, the Hausdorff dimension of the Cantor set is:

Hausdorff dimension = $\frac{\log 2}{\log 3} \approx 0.6309$

This value is the same regardless of the number of iterations k, as the process of removing the middle third of the line segments continues infinitely.
